Graphical abstract This review introduces the research progress of ORR/OER bifunctional carbon-based catalysts in recent years. The analysis of the mechanism and synergistic effects for the optimization strategy is mainly emphasized. Electrocatalysts are one of the essential components for the devices of high-efficiency green energy storage and conversion, such as metal-air cells, fuel cells, and water electrolysis systems. While catalysts made from noble metals possess high catalytic performance in both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), their scarcity and expensiveness significantly limit large-scale applications. In this regard, metal-free/non-noble metal carbon-based catalysts have become competitive alternatives to replace catalysts made of noble metals. Nevertheless, low catalytic ORR/OER performance is the challenge of carbon-based catalysts for the commercial applications of metal-air batteries. To solve the problem of poor catalytic performance, two strategies have been proposed: (1) controlling the microstructure of the catalysts to expose more active sites as the channels of rapid mass and electron transfer; and (2) reducing the reaction energy barrier by optimizing the electronic structures of the catalysts via surface engineering. Here, we review different types of bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts with the activated surface sites. We focus on how the challenge can be overcome with different methods of material synthesis, structural and surface characterization, performance validation/optimization, to outline the principles of surface modifications behind catalyst designs. In particular, we provide critical analysis in the challenges that we are facing in structural design and surface engineering of bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts and indicate the possible solution for these problems, providing the society with clearer ideas on the practical prospects of noble-metal-free electrocatalysts for their future applications. Keywords Electrocatalyst Bifunctionality Oxygen reduction Oxygen evolution Carbons transition metals Surface engineering Microstructure 1 Introduction The increasing shortage of the global supply of fossil fuels, and the environmental problems associated with their (inefficient) utilization, have imposed tremendous pressure on human society to seek alternative, clean and renewable sources of energy [1–7], particularly for the generation of electricity [8,9]. These alternatives include solar, wind, ocean waves, and so on [10–13]. Utilizing these energy sources requires materials and devices to be further developed for energy storage and conversions. Water electrolysis for hydrogen productions has been considered as one of the most promising technologies to be applied for a variety of energy utilization fields including fuel cells [14–20]. Among different types of metal-air batteries including lithium-air, aluminum-air, and zinc-air batteries have been identified as the next generation of technologies due to high energy densities [21–25]. For hydrogen generation, using electrochemical cells to split the water has been considered as the most promising approach that can provide cheap, sustainable, and clean electricity [26,27]. For metal-air batteries, the major challenge is the insufficient performance of cathodes when catalyzing the OER during the charging processing while the ORR during the discharge processing [28]. Hydrogen fuel cells have been developed for automobile applications due to high power densities and zero-emission [29], the slow ORR occurring at the cathode to convert the hydrogen to electricity is the main drawback to restrict their performance. Differently, the OER at the anode is the key factor limiting their performances for the fuel-cell-based water electrolysis. Developing electrocatalysts with high catalytic activity, chemical stability, and cost-effectiveness will establish a cross-cutting strategy to further enhance the performance of the aforementioned technologies, resulting in the technologies being feasible for large-scale industrialization [30–36]. To further understand and improve the catalytic performance of ORR/OER, it is necessary to analyze the mechanism of ORR and OER respectively. The oxygen adsorption and desorption represent the diffusion and exchange of oxygen, which is the key step in ORR catalysis. The oxygen can be effectively exchanged and reaction resistance can be reduced by balancing the adsorption and desorption of oxygen. Meanwhile, promoting the adsorption and desorption of oxygen species can increase the kinetic current and diffusion limiting current density, which affects the electrocatalytic performance [37]. The adsorption energy, binding energy, energy gap, and even the stability of the reaction can be evaluated by the adsorption bond [38]. It is generally believed that the way of oxygen species adsorption formed by different atom bonding can affect the potential barrier of subsequent reactions and will change the overall reaction mechanism of ORR. Two modes of oxygen adsorption exist in the reaction of oxygen: bidentate adsorption and terminal adsorption. The different effects of bidentate adsorption and terminal adsorption on the O-O bond energy are in favor of two different ORR pathways, i.e., four-electron transfer style without peroxide formation and two-electron transfer style with peroxide involved, respectively [39,40]. Seififitokaldani et al. verified the suitable adsorption configuration in different ORR reaction stages using the center value of d-band as the descriptor [41]. Two kinds of adsorption sites were summarized: bridge adsorption and top adsorption. The strong interaction between oxygen atoms and two bridging atoms reduces the d-band center and adsorption energy. During the subsequent formation of hydroxides, OH species were adsorbed more easily at the top site than at the bridging site. Finally, the bridging site has poor adsorption capacity for small molecular water, which is conducive to the desorption of water and can promote ORR activity. Therefore, the most favorable way of oxygen adsorption is the bridge configuration based on kinetic studies or density functional theory (DFT) calculations [42]. During the bidentate adsorption process of the bridge model, the O-O bond length increases, and the oxygen adsorption energy decreases significantly. The oxygen atom is activated by two catalyst atoms at the same time, so that more electrons enter the empty orbital of O2 to obtain better ORR catalytic activity [43]. Besides facilitating oxygen adsorption, the bridging model also has an active advantage in the step of oxygen dissociation to form two separated oxygen atoms. Ji et al. [44] specifically studied the mechanism of oxygen desorption under different 2D group IVA monochalcogenides. It was found that the distance between oxygen atoms is closely related to the dissociation barrier. Compared with the triplet oxygen distance (1.22 Å), the bridging structure has a more suitable distance (1.51 Å) of oxygen atom and a lower dissociation barrier. The distance of the dissociated O atom can be determined by the distance of the adsorption center, thus determining the adsorption energy of the O atom. Based on these clues, it is possible to design a bridge structure of oxygen adsorption pathway with the best atomic distance. The bond breaking and bonding process of intermediates is all preparations for the formation of O-O bonds in different OER mechanisms. According to different O-O bond formation steps, the researchers proposed two fundamentally different mechanisms: the acid-base mechanism and the direct coupling mechanism. Both of these mechanisms form -O species by oxidizing the metal sites of –OH groups. In the direct coupling mechanism, the formation of O-O bond can be directly coupled by two adjacent -O species to form O-O bond. The oxidation mechanism of lattice oxygen can directly affect the direct O-O coupling step. The lattice oxygen atoms rotate to a suitable angle, coupling and desorption occur to form oxygen vacancy. This coupling makes the intermediate adsorption and desorption steps independent of the change of metal–oxygen bond [45]. In the acid-base mechanism, the M (metal)-O group on metal sites is attacked by H2O in acidic medium or OH– in alkaline medium to form M−OOH species, and then M−OOH species are oxidized by the participation of H2O and lose protons to form M−OO species. The bond between metal and oxygen species breaks to produce oxygen at last [46]. Ping et al. substantiated that the O-end surface of IrO2 (110) is the most stable surface structure and studied the OER reaction mechanism from this adsorption surface [47]. Their research illustrates that the O atom at the top has the characteristics of free radicals is the active center of the new O-O bond and provides the conditions for the formation of O2. The possible mechanism of O-O bond formation is proposed: solvent water molecules attack the surface oxygen atoms to form O-O bonds. No matter which step the OER reaction takes, the research tasks are to promote the formation of O-O bonds and the breaking –OO bonds with low energy consumption. Currently, noble metals (Pt, Ru, and Ir) materials are the most suitable electrocatalysts for catalyzing the ORR and OER, enabling the high reaction rates for practical applications [48]. In particular, Pt-based catalysts show superior HER/ORR performance and Ru-based ones are good at OER catalysis [49]. The main drawbacks of noble metal catalysts are their high cost that is related to their low natural abundance, even though they are capable of delivering high catalytic performance while maintaining long-term stabilities. To further reduce the costs, strategies, such as alloying with other metals [50], structural and morphological engineering [51], and manipulation of surface strain [52,53], have been explored. At a fundamental level, these strategies are employed to optimize the content and distribution of noble metals in the matrix, in terms of the enhancement of their high catalytic activities and stabilities by changing their electronic structures [54,55]. Nevertheless, the benefit that comes from reducing the consumption of noble metals in these catalysts remains very limited. Therefore, the exploration of non-noble-metal-based, as well as metal-free electrocatalysts, with the enhanced co-catalytic activities for ORR and OER remain an ongoing challenge in the research community [56,57]. Carbon-based materials are often used as catalytic materials for various catalytic reactions due to their low-cost, wide sources, and high electrical conductivity [58–60]. However, carbon-based catalysts need to overcome some inherent shortcomings of carbon materials in order to be efficient and stable industrial-grade catalysts. The carbon material itself has weak mechanical strength, poor stability and cannot be regenerated in an oxidizing atmosphere. Metals on carbon supports tend to aggregate during the reaction and cause deactivation. In addition, the low density and poor adhesion of carbon-based materials are responsible for the instability of carbon-based catalysts [61], which deteriorates the catalytic performance of carbon-based catalysts in the ORR/OER dual reaction process. Structural design, doping and defect introduction, and attachment of metals and their oxides and MOF derivatives are effective strategies to optimize the inherent shortcomings of carbon-based catalysts [62,63]. The carbon-based catalysts come in many forms, such as active carbon, carbon cloth, single-layer/multilayer graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanosheets, and graphite, which provides the additional advantage in manipulating their catalytic powers through controlling their structural morphologies apart from being metal-free [64–67]. Further improvements in the catalytic activities of carbon-based catalysts can be achieved via a series of innovative strategies such as chemical doping, defect manipulations, and structure/morphology controls, as illustrated in Fig. 1 [68–70]. For example, Hu et al. [71] have prepared the catalyst of two-dimensional N, S co-doped graphitic sheets with stereoscopic pore structure on the surface of graphene (SHG). At the same time, they also compared its bifunctional ORR/OER activities with different kinds of common catalysts (Fig. 2 ). Compared with the discrete graphite capsules (GC) that are without continuous two-dimensional structure, and the N and S co-doped graphite sheets (GS) that are without three-dimensional pores, the combination of three-dimensional pore structure, doping, and defects had introduced more active sites in SHG, resulting in high electrical conductivity and excellent stability. The ΔE value (the difference between the OER potential at a 10 mA/cm2 and the ORR half-wave potential) of the SHG catalyst is lower than most metal-free/transition-metal carbon-based materials. Its catalytic activity is demonstrated to be even better than some commercial precious-metal catalysts, such as Ru/C, Pt/C, and RuO2. Only some single-atom transition-metal carbon-based catalysts, such as Co/N-C, have comparable catalytic activities with this SHG catalyst. Jia et al. [72] fabricated a catalyst of porous N-doped carbon nanocages (N-CCs) with large specific surface area by the interfacial assembly. Compared to the Pt/C, the ORR half-wave potential of N-CCs catalyst was more positive and reached 190 mV in 3 mM methanol. The catalytic activity of OER is comparable to Ru/C and better than Pt/C. This ubiquitous porous structure of N-CCs results in a balance between mass transfer and catalytic reaction, making it more durable and with enhanced resistance to methanol compared to Pt/C. Therefore, the work provided evidence that the catalytic performance of carbon-based bifunctional catalysts can be greatly improved through structural control and surface modification. The microstructure with a large specific surface area is constructed to expose more effective active sites. By doping atoms or forming functional groups on the surface, the electronic structure and chemical bond of catalysts can be changed to further improve the activity of carbon-based catalysts [73]. Exposing edge sites, creating defects, introducing heteroatoms, anchoring single atoms, and alloying all produce sites that exhibit higher activity for electrocatalytic reactions [74]. These active sites can be unsaturated coordination atoms related to the surface adsorption energy, or surface defects that optimize the coordination environment, or dopant atoms and carbon atoms with different electronegativity, or even metal and carbon substrates with strong interaction. This is the fundamental principle behind catalyst optimization, based on which non-precious-metal carbon-based bifunctional catalysts with high catalytic activity and cycle stability can be designed with a more rational and pragmatic approach [6,75–77]. Non-precious metal carbon-based materials have been widely explored as ORR/OER-related dual-functional catalysts. The improvements in the performances of non-noble metal carbon-based catalysts compared to metal-free carbon-based catalysts are due to the intrinsic characteristics of metals, the control of microscopic morphology, and the change of electronic structure/density as well as the synergistic interaction between metal and non-metal on the catalyst surface. These approaches can lower the reaction barrier of the intermediate products and accelerate the charge transfer, thus further optimizing the performance of non-noble metal carbon-based catalysts [78,79]. Furthermore, morphological designs have been proved to effectively generate a large number of exposed active sites. This subsequently reduces the use of adhesives for increasing the stability and conductivity of the catalyzed electrodes [80–83]. Surface and interfacial engineering, through introducing heteroatom(s) dopants and defects, surface strains, and electronic conductive species, have also been proved to be universal and effective methods for optimizing catalysts [84]. The high electron affinity and unique electronic structure of the doped elements can improve the adsorption rate to increase the catalytic efficiency [85]. Surface defects can strongly affect the catalytic reaction process to improve the catalytic performance. For example, the edge defects (zig-zag edge, armchair edge, and edge cavity structure) can increase the binding energies of the core electrons in the catalysts [86]. Various vacancy defects often form new connection configurations in the catalyst, for example, oxygen vacancies and intermediates can form new active centers through chemical bonding to react preferentially with oxygen-containing species [87]. The vacancy active centers also quicken the dissociation of O2 and regulate the adsorption of terminal active groups. The synergistic effect with these terminal species can accelerate the kinetics of the catalytic reaction [88]. Meanwhile, the introduction of defects and heteroatoms can change the microstructure, resulting in a large number of mesopores and edge defects exposing more active centers in the catalyst, thus improving the performance of ORR/OER [89]. In general, an ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst exhibits a structure/morphology, composition, and defects to achieve excellent catalytic performance suitable for practical applications in electrochemical devices for energy harvesting [90]. The latest developments in metal-free/non-noble metal carbon-based ORR/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts have been summarized by focusing on the mechanism of the reaction occurring at the active sites and the stabilities. Strategies for performance improvements including microstructure control, catalytic interface optimization, and heteroatom doping are also proposed. Zhao et al. [91] focused on the research progress of active sites in the preparation of ORR/OER catalysts related to transition metals and their oxides. The review provides mechanistic insights into the catalytic performance from the perspective of structural morphologies and corresponding electronic structures. It also summarizes many different technologies for synthesizing hybrid structures with advanced carbon materials and compares and analyzes different mechanisms for optimizing the interface to improve the catalytic activity. Zhang et al. [92] summarized the research progress of understanding the role and designing the structures of the active centers in the carbon-based bifunctional electrocatalysts such as doping, defects, and single-atom active centers, in which the corresponding synthesis strategies, theoretical advantages, as well as the optimized electrochemical performance, have been analyzed. The selectivity, binding mode, and synergistic effect of active sites in a variety of transition metal/carbon composites are clarified, and the internal evolution of active centers in the catalytic process is further analyzed. Although the concept of manipulating the catalytic behaviors of carbon-based catalysts is simple, the understanding of the catalytic mechanism is challenged by the lack of in-situ experimental characterization of the catalytic site and process that can be correlated with detailed analysis on the catalytic mechanisms. Many existing literatures have attributed the observed enhancements in the catalytic powers of the as-treated carbon-based catalysts to the so-called ‘synergistic effect’. Further research is needed to dissect how each one of the above-mentioned strategies contributes to the synergistic effect in enhancing the catalytic power of the carbon-based catalysts. In this review, we will provide a thorough analysis of the catalytic mechanism of carbon-based catalysts that are modified with (combinations of) different chemical dopants, structural defects, and metal, which enables us to establish our unique insights to the synergistic effect. In the optimized catalysts, the influences of dopants, defects, surface decorations, and interface interaction on the carbon π bond, catalytic active sites, conductivity, and band alignment result in synergistic effects which generate highly efficient ORR/OER catalytic performance. The synergistic effect is a result of the subtle balance among the concentrations and the spatial distribution of dopants, defect type and concentrations, decorated materials coupling with carbon, and interface interaction, which further proves the necessity of searching for the origination of synergistic effect to find the best balance. The current review summarizes the recent developments in the design and synthesis of the ORR/OER carbon-based catalysts, as well as the strategies to enhance their catalytic performance through optimizing their bulk and interfacial structures. The main topics of this work are systematically shown in Fig. 1. The structural design and surface engineering are effective methods to optimize the performance of carbon-based nonmetal or transition metal ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts. The correlation between the catalytic performance and the synthetic methods and material characterizations of various carbon-based bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts is analyzed. Furthermore, the effects of structural control and surface engineering on the reaction mechanisms of the bifunctional catalysts are revealed. This provides a guiding basis for the research and development of new high-efficiency catalysts through the electrical conductivity enhancement, modification of coordination environment, increasing of densities of active-sites, as well as the combination across these different strategies. Development paths in the promising field are also discussed based on the understanding of catalysts preparation method and optimization mechanism through this review, the future research directions related to energy conversion and utilization are proposed to overcome the fundamental limits to achieve the practical ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts for the metal-air battery. Different from the most recent published reviews that focused on the structural design and activity regulation methodologies [93,94], this review focuses on the fundamental principles behind different strategies for optimizing the catalytic performance, in particular, comprehensive analysis in the structural and electronic origins behind the observed enhancement of their catalytic performance. More specifically, we review the mechanisms behind the attenuation of the catalytic properties for carbon-based catalysts through the manipulations of interfaces, sizes, geometric shapes, and the cooperative effects among them are systematically analyzed, based on the latest developments in their synthesis and characterization techniques. Furthermore, we present the state-of-the-art mechanism on how the incorporations of dopants can further optimize the electrocatalytic properties. This inspired us to create comprehensive design rules for the fabrication of new-generation high-performance carbon-based catalysts. 2 Carbon-based non-metallic catalysts The versatility of carbon–carbon bonds and dimensional controllability of carbon-based materials are the two main advantages for designing low-cost and high-performance ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts [20]. However, purely carbon-based materials are generally inert to achieve strong surface adsorption of molecules, which is strongly desired for the activation of O2 and its intermediates. In this regard, it is necessary to modify carbon materials to activate their catalytic functionalities. There are three main control strategies: structural control, chemical doping, and defect manipulations. Through these strategies, the electron/mass transfers and electronic structures in the catalytic environment can be optimized, as well as constructing suitable stable structures, thus improving both their activities and stabilities (Table 1 ) [19,95,96]. 2.1 Heteroatom-doped carbons Different types of heteroatoms can be used for doping or co-doping the carbon to form heteroatoms-doped catalysts, which can effectively change the electronic structures and charge densities of the carbons. These doped atoms can also provide modifiable active groups for high-performance ORR/OER electrocatalysis [6,20,116]. The enhancement in the catalytic performances for the doped carbon materials can be mainly attributed to the synergy between the dopants, the adsorption configuration formed among the doping atoms, the carbon atoms, and the adsorbents, as well as the optimization of the electronic structure of carbon by the doping atoms to promote the formations of reactive intermediates thus lowering the overall reaction free energy barrier [97,98]. The synergy between the dopant atoms provides a selective and active group for the reactions catalyzed by the dual function [99]. The chemical bonds between the dopant and the carbon atoms can lead to the formations of unique atomic configurations, which act both as the active sites and the electron transport channels to collectively reduce the reaction energy barrier. The changes in the electronic structure of the carbon substrate induced by the dopant atoms make the carbon substrate graphitize to enhance the electrical conductivity and intrinsic activity of the substrate. Usually, the ΔE (ΔE = E j=10 - E 1/2) is used to express the ORR/OER dual catalytic performance. The smaller the ΔE lead the better the dual catalytic performance. The electronic structure of carbon materials can be tuned by various doping atoms, so that the bifunctional catalytic activity of metal-free carbon-based catalysts is comparable to that of noble metal catalysts [100–103]. Among these catalysts, heteroatom doping made a significant contribution to facilitating the ORR/OER catalytic reaction [104]. In the subsequent sections, the fundamental principles underlying the catalytic mechanisms of doping effects on the catalytic performances of carbon-based electrocatalysts are discussed to lay a theoretical foundation to select suitable dopants in future catalysts designs. 2.1.1 Mono-doping effects Heteroatom doping can induce both lattice distortions and changes in the electron density distributions, which activate the material as a catalyst. Typically, this introduces mid-gap electronic states that act as a bridge to lower the energy barriers for charge transfer between the catalyst and the adsorbents on the surface of the catalyst [117]. Therefore, understanding the nature of mid-gap states in heteroatom doped carbon catalysts is important to rationalize their corresponding catalytic performances. Mao et al. [118] have chosen the C–H activation in ethane molecules on the doped carbon catalysts as a model to study how the charge transport characteristics of doped carbon materials are affected from the perspective of electronic structure. The energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the carbon material have undergone major changes with the incorporation of different heteroatoms, as shown in Fig. 3 (a). The LUMO of undoped carbon and the HOMO of ethane has a large difference (∼ 1 eV), indicating the large energy barrier for charge transfer. B or N doping introduces singly occupied molecular orbitals (SOMOs) in the catalyst. The orbital energies of the SOMO or LUMO of undoped and single-element doped catalysts (such as S, B, N) are −4.16 eV, −3.61 eV, −4.66 eV, and −4.44 eV, respectively. They act as the electron acceptors to take up the electrons from the reactants. Electron transfer is promoted in the cases with relatively lower energy barriers, leading to the better catalytic activities of B and N doped catalysts than those of the undoped and S doped catalysts. The catalytic performance of carbon materials doped with different non-metal atoms (B, N, P, S) is closely related to the redistribution of charge densities in carbon materials, which has been proved by previous studies [119]. To gain an in-depth mechanism analysis behind the catalytic performances, it is necessary to further introduce the concept of adsorption energy level. Xie et al. [120] analyzed the partial density of states (PDOS) of carbon materials with different doping elements to study the mechanism of doping and adsorption on the catalytic performance of p-nitrophenol reduction. As shown in Fig. 3(b), with N, P, and O atoms doped into the carbon skeleton, the O atoms in the catalyst are bonded with the adsorbed H atoms to reduce p-nitrophenol. The electron in the s-orbital of the H atom overlaps with the electron in the p-orbital of the O atom. The partial density of states (PDOS) of the carbon material doped with only P atoms is shown in Fig. 3(c). Compared with carbon materials doped with N, O, and P atoms, catalysts without N and O atoms can only rely mainly on the orbital overlap of doped P atoms and H atoms to optimize adsorption. The O atom and H atom have a larger electron orbital overlap than the P atom and H atom, indicating that the O atom can optimize the catalyst's ability to adsorb H atoms. The carbon material catalysts doped with N, P, and O atoms exhibit intensive orbital overlaps, indicating that the adsorption strengths for the surface reactants of the catalysts are stronger and the electrons have a higher potential to be transferred within the materials. Fundamentally, the dopant changes both the electronic energy levels and the localized electron distributions around the dopant, thus making them an active site for catalyzing the chemical reactions. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the valence band (v) of the active site overlaps the bonding (σ) orbital of the adsorbed atom, forming a bonding (v-σ) and anti-bonding (v-σ)* state [121]. Doping one or more active atoms in carbon can better adjust the valence orbital energy level, thereby optimizing the bonding and anti-bonding states. The higher active center orbital energy caused by doping can reduce the filling of anti-bonded states to optimize the adsorption of intermediates and accelerate the progress of the catalytic reaction. This is the fundamental physics behind the catalytic performance enhancement of carbon materials with the heteroatom incorporations. Among the different heteroatoms, the N element is a widely used doping element, which can give rise to the most optimal adsorption/coordination configuration when coordinated with C [122]. Different N-C configurations, such as graphitic-N, pyrrolic-N, and pyridinic-N (Fig. 4 a), have been reported [123]. The pyridinic-N and graphitic-N have been shown to have the highest intrinsic catalytic activities than the other forms [124]. In general, surface modification or engineering can improve the catalytic activity of an N-doped ORR/OER electrocatalyst in two aspects: (1) one is the increase of the intrinsic activity originated from the nitrogen-carbon bonds that are electronically different from the carbon–carbon bonds; and (2) another is the increase of effective active sites [105]. The effective combination of N element and carbon can adjust the function of the NC configuration by changing the structure of the carbon substrate to increase the effective active sites [125]. For example, Sun et al. [105] designed a simple two-step method (hydrothermal and calcination), which could grow N-doped holey carbon layer (N-HC) on the graphene oxide (GO) substrate. Pyridinic-N in N-HC is selectively used as the active center of ORR/OER. These catalysts have a high pyridinic-N content, indicating that the selective doping of pyridinic-N (Fig. 4b) is favorable to the HC structure. GO sheets were reduced to graphene through the hydrothermal process. These graphene sheets provided structural support to stabilize N-HC, promoting the charge transfer to increase the catalytic activity and stability. Therefore, the doped nitrogen and the substrate that can produce an effective adsorption configuration showed an effective synergetic effect for improving the catalytic performance [126]. Xu et al. [96] studied the atomic bonding structures of various N-doped carbon nanotubes/graphene hybrid catalysts, and C=C, C-N and O-C=O bond structures could all be found in the catalyst matrix. The structural characteristics of carbon were further studied by Raman spectroscopy, and the results are shown in Fig. 4(c). The relative intensity of the D-band and G-band reveals that the interaction between nitrogen atoms and the surrounding carbon atoms induces a significant portion of graphitization. The enhanced graphitization makes the carbon atoms transformed from the disordered layer structure to the ordered graphite crystals, which are highly conductive to improve the charge transfer rate and their corresponding catalytic activities. An in-depth mechanistic analysis of graphitic-N and pyridinic-N can understand their role in catalytic reactions. It is generally believed that pyridinic-N is not the most critical activity-promoting factor. The role of pyridinic-N is to promote the conversion of the two-electron mechanism of ORR into a four-electron mechanism [127]. Graphitic-N may be the key to improving the catalytic activity. Graphitic-N is an edge N atom existing in the C lattice and combined with three C atoms. This configuration can facilitate electron transfer from C to O via N and lower the molecular dissociation barrier of oxygen. Liu et al. [128] investigated the effect of N species on graphitic-nitrogen-rich nitrogen-doped graphene sheets (NrGO) on ORR catalytic activity by DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 4(d and e), the analysis of the atomic distance and binding energy indicates that O atoms are more likely to bind to the pyrrolic-N site and the graphitic-N site but not to pyridinic-N. The average local ionization energy (ALIE) of the molecular surface shows a minimum near the graphitic-N, reflecting the highest electron reactivity (Fig. 4f). Whereas in pyrrolic-N there is no minimum. This higher electron reactivity proves that the catalytic reaction occurs on the graphitic-N sites. P and S elements with unique physical and chemical properties can also be used as common dopants for surface modification of carbon matrix. The improved electrocatalytic activity of carbon catalysts doped with the heteroatoms is partially due to the different electronegativity between different atoms. For example, the N-doped carbon atoms introduce additional positive charges, resulting in stronger oxygen adsorption. S atom replacements reduce the amount of oxygen functional groups in the graphene to result in higher catalytic activity and stability through adjusting the electronegativity. Lee et al. [106] prepared the S-doped graphene nanocrystals (SDGNS) using thiosulphates as the sulfur source and electrochemical stripping at room temperature. The purpose of using thiosulfate as a doping source was to make the carbon in graphene be replaced by sulfur through reaction (1): S2O3 2-+SO4 2-+2H+→S + SO2 + SO4 2-+H2O(1) Compared with the other doping groups, such as S or SO2 on the edge of graphene and sulfur ring on graphene, the S atoms and oxygen-containing functional groups induce the most stable structure through the strong electrostatic interaction. Compared with the relative intensities of the D-band and G-band of graphene without S doping, S doping could significantly enhance the concentration of defects in the catalyst. The P element doping can optimize the electron transfer ability and adsorption activity by adjusting the electronic structure and density through the covalent bonding and the charge redistribution on the surface. Yang et al. [129] synthesized the P-doped carbon nanotubes (P-CNT) by a one-step in-situ solvothermal reaction. The P doping to carbon and the strengthening of the chemical bond between P and carbon led to the change of electronic structure in the active center, providing additional p-electrons for the conjugated carbon system and inducing the formation of electron donor/acceptor sites. The catalyzed ORR by this catalyst was a four-electron process, and its catalytic process and activity are similar to commercial Pt/C (20 wt%). And the OER catalytic activity of such a P-CNT was higher than Pt/C. The choices of doping elements and doping sites are important in the preparation of highly stable and actively doped catalysts (Fig. 4g) [130]. As discussed in the S [106] and P [129] monodoping cases, the important requirement for selecting dopants is the proper electronegativity between heteroatoms. The distance between the dopants and the active sites on the doped catalyst can strongly affect the electrode overpotential. The doped site should be close to the active sites (defects and edge sites). The adsorption strength of intermediates on the active sites formed by the N, P, or S element can affect the reaction kinetics [131]. In this regard, the positions in the volcanic maps can be used as the reference to select the appropriate dopants, as shown in Fig. 4(h and i) [130]. In general, the selection of these doping positions and element types needs to meet the appropriate electron density and electronegativity difference for greatly optimizing the electronic structure and adsorption structure, to increase the active center and promote the adsorption of oxygen on the catalyst surface. 2.1.2 Multiple-doping effects The interaction between multiple dopant elements can also form favorable geometries compared to single element doping, leading to electronic structures that are favored for catalytic purposes [99,132,133]. Co-doing by multiple elements can provide more modified active groups and enhancement in the synergistic effect for the catalytic reactions [107,115]. Dai et al. [134] prepared B and N co-doped carbon nanotubes (VA-BCN) through the pyrolysis of melamine diporate to explore the co-doping effect. They compared the catalytic activity of VA-BCN with the corresponding products doped with either N or B atoms (i.e., VA-BCNT or VA-NCNT), respectively, and found that the synergistic effect induced by the co-doping of N and B produces excellent overpotential and current density in VA-BCN for the ORR process. This is partly because the B and N dopants not only provide carbon nanotubes with excellent thermal stability but also tune the bandgap energies of the carbon nanotubes. On the other hand, the active sites of N and B atoms transfer electrons to the surrounding carbon atoms. Zou et al. [100] used the self-sacrificial template method to carbonize the polydopamine-encapsulated melamine-trithiocyanurim copolymers and obtained N, S hollow co-doped carbon tubes (NSCHCT). The porous structure exhibits high mass transfer efficiency and a large number of active sites. More importantly, multiple heteroatom doping provides various active sites, such as the special configuration formed by the combination of thiophene-sulfur and pyridinic-N (p-N/S) optimizes the electronic structure and shows the lowest activation energy barrier of ORR/OER. Fan et al. [107] reported a novel three-dimensional S and N co-doped carbon nanocage for ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance of this catalyst originated from the mutual electronic interactions among S and N dopants, abundant defects, Large active specific surface area, multi-scale structure, and high electrical conductivity. This kind of electron interaction could be manifested in the process of charge transfer from S-doped species to N-doped ones. The catalyst was rich in C-S-C, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N doped configurations, which made the surrounding C atoms positively charged, resulting in a desirable electronic structure for promoting the adsorption of intermediate products. Through the analysis of dopant configurations and intermediate products, they also found that the pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and thiophene-S can all affect ORR activity, while OER activity was mainly delivered by thiophene-S and pyridinic-N species. The changes in orbital energy level caused by the different dopants affect the charge transfer [135]. In addition, different doping elements have different adsorption selectivity for the reaction intermediates. Ying et al. [136] introduced N, S into graphdiyne to regulate the OER catalysis. The sp-N is the dominant configuration, which can reduce the overpotential of carbon-based catalysts. The introduction of S atoms is mainly to adjust the current density. According to the electronic interaction between different elements, the difference of electronegativity and other conditions can be matched with a selective atom bonding structure to optimize the bifunctional catalytic reaction. Multi-faceted research is needed for synergistic effects through pairing the right elements. The synergistic effect induced by multi-element doping has been extensively investigated to strengthen the catalytic power of the catalysts, such as high selectivity, anti-poisoning, high charge transfer, adsorption configuration, electron density variation, and surface variation [136-138]. Similarly, the synergistic interaction of different doping elements can also be observed and measured in ORR/OER carbon-based bifunctional catalysts [139,140]. Kim et al. [141] prepared N, S co-doped carbon nanoweb (NSCNW) as electrocatalyst for CO2 reduction and explored the synergistic effect of double-doping. They found that a large amount of thiophene-like S over oxidized S was formed after doping with S, which changed the electronic structure of the N-position of pyridinic and improved the catalytic activity. Jiang et al. [142] synthesized an N, S co-doped graphene nanosheet (NSG) with graphitic-N and thiophenic-S by pyrolysis. The ratio between graphitic-N and thiophenic-S was adjusted by adjusting the mass ratio of N and S sources. A moderate ratio (the mass ratio of N source and S source is 1:1) of graphitic-N and thiophene S could enhance the ORR activity, while a higher ratio (the mass ratio of N source and S source is 3:1) was beneficial to OER. The effects of different ratios of N and S products on different reaction selectivity were further analyzed by DFT. Carbon atoms with high charge and spin density in the model have a great influence on the adsorption of intermediates and can serve as the most efficient active sites, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). Compared with single-element N doping, the co-doping of N and S leads to uneven distribution of charge and spin density and increases the number of activated carbon atoms. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the graphitic-N + thiophenic-S model has the lowest ORR overpotential, which is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect of graphitic N and thiophenic S promoting the oxygen adsorption capacity of activated carbon atoms. As shown in Fig. 5(c), 2 graphitic-N + thiophenic-S exhibited the smallest OER overpotential, while more thiophenic S did not promote the catalytic activity of OER. Fig. 5(d) visualizes the electronic structure changes for part of the model, with the graphitic N and thiophene S configurations producing extensive electron redistribution near the doped heteroatoms. Xia et al. [143] screened the influence of the dopants’ locations on the electron density and coordination environment in N-X co-doped graphene (X = B, P, S, and Cl), as shown in Fig. 6 (a). They have defined a descriptor Φ (Φ = (E X/E C) × (A X/A C)), which is the product of electronegativity (E X) and electron affinity (A X) with the subscripts to indicate the dopant element X. The large difference in the descriptor (Φ) results in the low overpotential originated from the strong electronic interactions between these two heteroatom dopants. The lower overpotentials of ORR and OER are shown in the dual-element doped carbon catalysts compared with the single-element doped ones, as shown in Fig. 6(b), leading to the improvement of catalytic performance. The distance between these dopants in the carbon matrix also strongly affects the catalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 6(c and d). The results indicate that the element combination and the dopant distance that is determined by the equilibrium atomic interaction are the key catalytic performance factors in ORR and OER. Such a synergistic effect dominates the electron density and coordination environment. Manipulating the defect position and the ratio of doping atoms can adjust the position of the doping element. The optimization of element pairing and their doping positions is an effective strategy for tapping the potential of doping effects of carbon-based catalysts. The combined effect of different elements comes from the elements that are spatially separated in the carbon matrix. If the doping elements are bonded together, the coordination environment is not favorable for the catalytic functions. In the B and N co-doped carbon substrate in which the B and N elements are separated from each other, B is used as an electron acceptor while N is used as an electron donor to improve the electron mobility through combining with the carbon π system [144,145]. The concentration of B- and N-doping elements can also be controlled by changing the heating temperature [146]. Therefore, changing the experimental conditions, such as pyrolysis temperature and reactant concentration can control the doping level and optimize the spatial arrangements of the dopants. In this regard, it is necessary to carefully control the spatial configurations among multiple dopant elements to achieve the spatial uniformity of the dopant atoms. For example, Zhao et al. [147] prepared the N-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and B, N co-doped CNTs to study the influence of the dopant distributions in CNTs on their catalytic activity. The direct chemical bonding between a B and N dopant would not change the original catalytic inertness of carbon materials. This is because the lone electron pair of the N element is accommodated by the empty orbital of the B element. As such, the occupied and empty orbitals cannot conjugate with the carbon π system, making it difficult to activate π electrons. However, when B and N dopants are spatially separated in the carbon matrix, it prevents the electron donor from neutralizing the electron acceptor and retaining the ability to conjugate. The spatially-separated doping elements then act as the electron acceptors/donors to further enhance electron transfer. Li et al. [148] synthesized the doped graphene monomer and nano-pore through a one-step chemical method and then introduced dopant atoms into the graphene structure. Through interlayer thermal-polymerization and pyrolysis of the layered carbides by glucose and boric acid, they obtained a B and N co-doped holey graphene assembly (BNHG). This indicates that heteroatom doping can adjust the valence band and conduction band edges, increase the bandgap, and lead to changes in the performance of the carbon materials. The B and N act as electron acceptors and donors respectively, which fundamentally reduces the HOMO and increases the LUMO. This induces electron relocation to activate the reactant and oxygen for the oxidation reaction. The separated B and N atoms optimize the electronic structure, resulting in excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. The synergistic effect of co-doping with three elements is more complicated when the bifunctional catalytic activity is largely attributed to the interaction amongst three different elements. For example, Wang et al. [108] used a defect-assisted in-situ pyrolysis method to prepare N, S, and P triple-doped graphene (NSP-Gra) with superior electrocatalytic oxygen reaction. In addition to different active groups which have selective effects on OER and ORR, the excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance is mainly due to the different electronegative non-metallic element pairs judging from the research and analysis of its structure and catalytic kinetics process. Shinde et al. [109] prepared an ORR/OER catalyst with three-dimensional carbon nanoparticles embedded by a P and S co-doped carbon nitride through polymerization and pyrolysis of aminoguanidine. P and adjacent N form a P-N bond through a covalent bond. The interaction between the P-N bond and π-conjugated tetrazine ring made positive charged P to be the active center. S doping could induce the synthesis of thiophene or benzothiadiazole structure with adjacent carbon as active sites. Therefore, the excellent catalytic performance of the multi-doped catalysts is largely derived from the special structure formed by the doped elements. These special structures can work together to promote mass/electron transfers, strengthen carbon delocalization π bonds, and form different catalytically active sites. As discussed above, carbon nanomaterials doped with N, P, S, and B can form many active species in carbon-based catalysts. The doping species can activate the electron donor or acceptor states of different reactions through the generation of favorable bandgap, electronic structure, and density of states, which then determines the energy consumption of charge transfer and the number of free radicals. The modulation of electrons can control the electronic structure and distribution of the matrix, thereby affecting the generation of active centers. Furthermore, the generated active centers can affect the interaction of reaction intermediates, reduce electrode overpotential and improve catalytic activity. In addition, the configurations of some doping species can also provide a stable reaction pathway. The combined effect of these factors above can effectively improve the performance of the bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts [149–152]. Effective control of the synergistic effect with multiple element doping is non-trivial because the synergistic effect is interdependent upon a multitude of factors including the dopant distribution, defect generations, crystal structure transitions, microstructure reconstructions, surface modifications, interface participation, and the mutual interactions among these factors. Using Marcus charge transfer theory and the change of orbital energy level introduced by doping, the synergistic effect can be revealed, at least semi-quantitatively, in an ideal simple system [153]. Zhuang et al. [155] have proposed a direct strategy to investigate the synergistic effect between surface atoms using STM, which is illustrated in Fig. 7 (a-c). In principle, this synergistic effect reflects the change in interactions among different surface adsorbents. When different atoms adsorbed on different surfaces are spatially close enough to induce substantial orbital overlaps/interactions between the adsorbents, electron transfer reaction occurs more readily, resulting in a significant change in the STM signal. Therefore, using the STM technique, it is possible to smoothly probe the electron transfer rate by the interatomic distances between two adsorbent atoms on the surfaces. As such, the experimentally measured STM current can be applied to quantify the synergistic effects induced by the proximity coupling between different atoms on the catalytic surface. Mück-Lichtenfeld et al have explored the synergistic effects in H2-activation with BP-frustrated Lewis as the organic catalysts [154]. They have proposed two parameters to quantify the synergistic effects, namely, the three-body interaction energy and the activation energy for the chemical reactions. The three-body interaction energy for a system with three interacting bodies is defined as δ E = Δ E total - Δ E AB - Δ E AC - Δ E BC with Δ E t o t a l = E A B C - E A - E B - E C , as illustrated in Fig. 7(d). A non-synergy system has a δ E value of zero. A negative δ E indicates the synergistic effect in the system while a positive δ E value indicates the anti-synergistic behavior among the three interacting components. Fig. 7(e-h) shows a comparison of catalytic strength with the activation energy in a system, in which the source material C is converted into product P under the catalysis of A-B, A, and B, respectively. Fig. 7(h) demonstrates the possible variation of the activation energy in the AB system compared with those of the isolated A or B system. Considering the difference between the energy barriers, the kinetics activation energy δ E kin is defined as δ E kin = E a A - E a AB in the system of E a A < E a B or δ E kin = E a B - E a AB in the system of E a A > E a B . The synergistic effect is indicated by δ E k i n > 0 in the overall system. δ E kin = 0 corresponds to a catalytic system with E a A = E a A B and E a A < E a B . The function of B is as a spectator without involving in the reaction. A negative δ E kin means both A and B are involved in the reaction but the A-B combination results in an anti-synergistic effect. Similar strategies were used to further study the doping or multi-doping effects on ORR/OER by quantifying the synergistic effects in heterogeneous catalysts. It is noted that the intervention of different atoms always produces unexpected diversification of phases, microstructures, and electronic structures. Therefore, the complex interactions between many influencing factors are difficult to accurately track the synergistic effects in most catalytic materials. 2.2 Defective carbon The catalytic ORR activities of pristine carbon materials are relatively poor. Even with the doping of N, the improvement in the catalytic performance is very limited. This may be associated with the insufficient effective active sites induced by the dopants or the lack of defective sites. Defects in the catalysts have been considered to be an additional factor to improve the performance of carbon-based nonmetallic ORR/OER catalysts [156,157]. Defect engineering can optimize the reaction adsorption energy [158,159]. For example, vacancy defects in bifunctional catalysts can adjust the electronic properties to improve conductivity and optimize the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates [160,161]. The lattice distortion and vacancy defects induced by the strong coupling in the heterogeneous interface can provide abundant active sites [162]. Moreover, the introduction of defects also facilitates the uniformity of heteroatom doping, further optimizing the electronic structure [108,163]. In this aspect, current research is mainly on topology defects and edge defects to maximize ORR/OER catalytic performance [164]. Edge defects have unsaturated active sites, dangling bonds, and edge sites that are easy to be functionalized. Topological defects contain defect sites to anchor dopant atoms. The carbon rings around the topological defects also lead to the generation of additional dipoles. These features provide a platform to optimize the environment around the defect and the electron density around the dopant atoms. Defects and doping are usually co-existed as a combined strategy for optimizing the performances of catalysts. The defect sites on the carbon substrate are easily replaced by the doped atoms, thereby regulating the degree of defects in the catalyst to enhance the synergistic effect. The effect of defects on carbon materials can make the bifunctional catalytic activity of non-metallic catalysts comparable to that of excellent noble metal catalysts [111,112]. The catalytic performance of most catalysts is related to the degree of defects, but the effects of the specific defects and their location are also important for catalytic performance, making the understanding of the mechanism of their effects on the catalytic performance to be critical. 2.2.1 Defect optimization principle Defects improve the catalytic activity of substrate by optimizing the electronic structure and density distributions around the defects in the carbon materials for different catalytic reactions [165]. The local strain energy induced by the defect activates the surrounding carbon atoms, which reduces the reaction activation energy for the catalytic reactions occurring at the defect sites [159]. Xia et al. [166] have determined the electronic structure of the specific defects in carbon materials and analyzed their influences on catalytic performance. Fig. 8 (a-d) compares the charge density variation induced by the vacancies, edge defects, and polygonal defects against the defect-free carbon. It shows that the defects induce a higher spin-charge density of carbon atoms. The high charge density on carbon atoms makes them able to donate electrons to the adsorbed molecules with low charge-transfer energy barriers and thus serve as active centers, resulting in excellent catalytic activity. The spin and charge density variation induced by the defects can match the electronic energy levels of the different catalytic intermediates, thus further enhancing the selectivity in OER or ORR [167]. Jiang et al. [168] studied the free energy of ORR process with the specific defects and the onset potential range of different defect carbon materials through DFT. The free energies for the formation of intermediates become lower than that of the pristine carbon, as shown in Fig. 8(e). The free energy of OOH* formation of original carbon materials and armchair edge defects is too high to activate the ORR process. The range of the initial potential further illustrates the selectivity of the defect to the adsorption of the intermediate (Fig. 8f), demonstrating the effect of the defect on the catalytic activity. The theoretical onset potential of carbon materials with different defects is higher than the experimentally observed potential for the pristine carbon (0.11 V), showing the defects can generate higher catalytic activity. As such, manipulating the defects can control the potential barrier of each catalytic step by optimizing the electron density and improving the ORR/OER catalytic performance effectively. 2.2.2 Edge defects on N-doped carbon materials The edge defects activate π electrons of carbons to effectively promote the generation of new active centers and transfer electrons to O2 during ORR. The interaction of doping and defects can promote charge rearrangement and intermediate transfer. Jiang et al. [113] prepared the N-doped ultra-thin carbon nanosheets (NCNs) by pyrolysis of citric acid and NH4Cl with a spontaneous gas-foaming process. During the preparation of the catalyst, the NH3 produced by the pyrolysis of NH4Cl under the instantaneous high-pressure resulted in the carbon matrix being rich in edge defects. The N-doped carbon formed more edge and topological defects in the high-temperature pyrolysis. The high-temperature pyrolysis of this ultra-flaky carbon structure further modifies the porosity and material thickness, resulting in many edge defects. The abundant defect in NCNs provided enough ORR and OER active centers. The gas generation process creates many micropores in the catalyst. The presence of micro-mesopores can produce more structural defects, which exposes more active centers and promotes mass transfer. The volcano diagram shown in Fig. 9 (a) depicts the correlation between adsorption energy and catalytic activity of N at different sites, i.e., 1gN-1, 1pdN-1, and 1prN-1, which represent graphitic-N, pyridinic-N, and pyrrolic-N, respectively. The position of 1gN-1 is more important in the adsorption reaction on graphitic-N. This facilitates the adsorption of O atoms with high electronegativity. The A-1 site is the carbon atom adjacent to the graphitic nitrogen dopant, which is located at the edge of armchair nanoribbons. The position of 1gN-1 is critical for bifunctional catalytic activity because the edge of the armchair can interact most strongly with oxygen, as shown in Fig. 9(b and d). For OER, the best active center is the carbon atom at A-5, which is 3.34 Å apart from the edge of the armchair belt and close to the graphitic-N dopant, as shown in Fig. 9(c). Therefore, the defect adjusts the electron and configuration of the catalytic interface and optimizes the adsorption energy. The DFT calculations further revealed that the ORR and OER intrinsic activity centers were the carbon atoms near the graphitic nitrogen at the edge of the armchair. For example, Wang et al. [110] introduced several N atoms at the zigzag edge to gain a deeper understanding of the effects of edge defects and N doping synergy on the carbon substrates. The DFT calculation indicates that a negative charge was generated on the N atom, and a positive charge was formed on the surrounding C sites when an N atom was doped on the edge carbon. The charge density was rearranged with each additional N atom with the increased N doping concentration. This charge redistribution increases the charge differences between adjacent electronic regions, speeds up charge transfer, and increases the likelihood for catalytic reactions to occur. Theoretically, it is found that the interaction of edge defects and doped N atoms can reduce the catalytic reaction barrier and increase adjacent active reaction sites with positive charges. 2.2.3 Topological defects on N-doped carbon materials Catalytic activity and stability are affected by the content and types of high-energy defects with many unsaturation centers, bonds, and thermodynamic instability [110]. Topological defects can improve the catalytic efficiency through the strong interaction between the defect site and the dopants anchored to it. For example, Liu et al. [169] prepared graphene-like and defect-rich carbon sheets with N-doping (GPNCS) through a hydrothermal method. The N-doped carbon matrix not only formed a more effective activation structure but also formed more defects in GPNCS. The doping of N atoms could optimize the electron cloud density, thus changing the bond length and bond strengths of C-N and C–C bonds to alter the carbon network in graphene thus producing active defects. The combination of the doped N atoms enriched in the topological defects and the unsaturated sites at the defect which in terms produce more active centers. The strong binding at the active site could improve the oxygen reaction kinetics, and provide significant ORR electrocatalytic activity and moderate OER performance. The pores and high specific surface area of the porous carbon framework were conductive due to the rapid diffusion of ions raised from increased adsorption at the active site. GPNCS are rich in defect structures (edges, pores, bifurcations, and cracks) to provide more active sites. Therefore, the combination of various topological and edge defects with doped elements has advantages. Zhang et al. [114] used chemical oxidation and decompression to construct a defect-rich N-doped ultra-microwave graphene nanoribbon (DN-UGNR). The topological defects of the carbon matrix (pentagonal and heptagonal carbon rings) in DN-UGNR could generate OER active centers. This was mainly caused by weak adsorption of the OH* on the original N-doped graphene nanoribbons. When the topological defects (pentagonal carbon ring C5 and heptagonal carbon ring C7) and the N-dopant coexisted in this catalyst, the electronic properties of the carbon atom were changed, strengthening the binding strengths of the reaction intermediates with the catalyst. These factors worked together to change the adsorption energy of OH* to an optimal value. Different structural edges and defects were combined to form active centers, such as the composite active center of pyridinic-N and pentagon defect on the edge of the armchair labeled as A-PN + C5 (Fig. 9d). As shown in Fig. 9(f), highly active electrocatalytic sites (Z-PN + C5 for ORR, and A-PN + C5 for OER) can be found on the volcanic map. Moreover, the adsorption configuration of the intermediate radicals in the defect active centers can be improved (Fig. 9g and h). The pentagonal carbon ring C5 and serrated edge can reduce the ORR reaction free energy and promote the electron transfer of OOH* [168]. The distortion of pentagonal carbon rings with different electron densities leads to charge redistribution and spatial curvature generation in the catalytic ORR/OER processes by forming a permanent dipole moment for lower adsorption energy. The molecular force produced by the transient dipole between the carbon rings could easily break the O-O bond and promote the progress of oxygen reduction [56,170]. In brief, the goal of introducing defects is to change the catalytic properties of the carbon matrix and obtain high bifunctional ORR/OER activity and stability. However, different types of defects can enhance the catalytic activities for different stages of the reaction cycle. The unsaturated sites and dangling bonds of edge defects can provide the basis for the formation of active sites. The edge sites are easily functionalized by the carbonyl (C=O) and hydroxyl (C-OH) groups. The functional configuration of the armchair and the active sites of the zigzag edge can change the local coordination environment to achieve high catalytic activity [171]. Topological defects work more efficiently on optimizing the adsorption and formation of intermediates. The adsorption energy of intermediates can be regulated by the dipole formed between the carbon rings to change the catalytic activity. These inherent defects have been proved to change the electronic structure and charge distribution for optimizing catalytic activity. However, the effect of defects on the catalyst still needs to be further studied to develop more efficient bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts, such as using in-situ technologies to understand the catalytic mechanism for developing different types of favorable defects [172]. 3 Carbon-based metal catalysts Along with the development of carbon-based non-metallic catalysts discussed above, the observation of the coupling effect of carbon materials with metal species has established a pathway to understand catalysts [173–175]. Another effective strategy for improving the performance of the catalysts is to combine the heteroatom modified electronic conductive carbon substrates with non-noble metal catalysts (transition metals and their oxides, phosphides, sulfides) (Table 2 ) [192–199,204–206]. The direct chemical connection between metals and metal compounds with carbon matrix suffers from the high formation energy and instability of metal–carbon bonds. The non-metallic elements activated carbons become the choice as carbon-based metal catalyst ligands. While compared to the widely studied TM-N-C configuration, few studies show the P, S, and B activation effects of carbon connection with metals or metal alloys as ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts. This is mainly due to the large atomic radius and charges mismatch of P, S, and B with the carbon atoms that leads to the lattice distortion and unstable coordination environment [176]. For example, the P element doped in carbon causes lattice expansion due to its large atomic radius and low electronegativity, resulting in a twisted configuration between P and C. Such a configuration easily forms PO x and hinders the formation of P sites or defects. [177]. These factors greatly affect the electronic and geometric coordination environment of the carbon-based catalyst. Nitrogen is a perfect alternative to carbon in the carbon matrix because of the similar atomic radii of nitrogen and carbon. Another advantage of nitrogen in the carbon matrix is easy to bind with metal ions forming a stable M−N x −C coordination environment. Nitrogen has become the dominant element in carbon-based metal catalysts because its presence can improve the catalytic performance with a synergistic effect via the M−N x −C structure [178]. This synergistic effect is mainly reflected in the strong coupling formed between N and metal to optimize the adsorption of intermediates and the occurrence of reversible ORR/OER processes. Studies have shown that the M−N x −C structure formed by the coordination of metal and nitrogen is the active center of the ORR catalytic process [179]. The transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (TM-N-C) structure is currently comprehensively and in-depth studied due to its superior atom utilization, controllable atom coordination environment, unique quantum effects, and adjustable metal-carrier interaction [180,181]. Our review provides an exhaustive mechanistic analysis of the interactions among metals, N, and C. The interaction of metals and N-C is discussed from the perspectives of energy level, adsorption bonding, electron transfer, and structural control, which may provide a possible route for the optimization strategy of ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts. 3.1 Metal / N-doped carbon hybrid catalysts The carbon serving as the substrate not only provides a stable matrix for the transition metal but also influences the electron density of metal atoms by the strong interfacial interaction between carbon substrate and the metal. This interaction can make the metal and adjacent carbon atoms form additional active centers, thus improving the electrocatalytic activity [207]. The differences in electronegativities among metal and N-C configuration can promote electron transfer. The metal-N-C with a special electronic structure can be used as a new active center [208]. Moreover, metal-N coordination can achieve a space-limiting effect, preventing metal from escaping from the substrate [180]. The effect of adding metal to N-doped carbon materials can be reflected in three stages: the process of active center formation, the process of adsorption of intermediates, and the process of metal optimizing the coordination environment and electronic structure of surrounding atoms, as shown in Fig. 10 . When N atoms are embedded in the carbon substrate, they can trap and anchor free metal atoms, thereby forming a metal-N-C bridge structure to promote efficient electron transfer. The carbon substrate can protect the metal-N-C structure through a special microstructure and a strong interface reaction during the catalytic reaction. Simultaneously, the metal will optimize the electron density of carbon atoms and activate carbon atoms. The synergistic effect between metal atoms is reflected in the different valence of metal atoms with selectivity for different catalytic reaction processes. The interaction and influence between metals, nitrogen, and carbon is an important prerequisite for obtaining excellent bifunctional catalytic activity [209–211]. 3.1.1 Effect of transition metal atoms The addition of transition metal atoms in N-doped carbon materials can further improve the catalytic performance by optimizing the electronic structures. An in-depth understanding of the optimization effect can help to figure out the mechanism of catalytic reactions and select suitable transition metals for synthesizing high-efficiency catalysts [212]. The special d orbitals of transition metals can either provide or accept electrons, providing an effective reaction basis for catalysis. More specifically, the position of the transition metal's d-band center energy level can strongly affect the adsorption of key intermediates such as OH* species. Xu et al. [213] studied the design principles for the graphene-based single-atom catalysts for ORR, OER and HER. They linked the activity with the local environment of the active center, such as the electronegativity and coordination atoms in the active center, and provided valuable guidance for the utilization of transition metals. The d-orbitals of metal atoms are related to the coupling of OH* species and metal, as shown in Fig. 11 (a). The ΔG OH* dependence on the valence electron in d-orbital metal elements (θ d) has been employed to describe the catalytic activity of different materials because of the significant influence of the occupied d orbital on the adsorption strength [214]. But the dependence is found to be empirical from the wide scattering of the plotted data point due to the redistribution of θ d coming from the influence of adsorbates on the metal atoms. A descriptor φ is established to correlate the catalytic activity center with the adsorption strength to illustrate the influence of the coordination environment and the adsorption strength on the activity, i.e., φ = θ d × E M + α × n N × E N + n C × E C E O , where α is the correction coefficient, E M, E O, E N, and E C represent the electronegativity of metal, O, N, and C elements, and n N and n C indicate the number of atoms of the nearest neighbors N and C.Then, the ΔG OH* dependence on φ was concluded as Δ G O H ∗ = 0.11 × φ - 2.48 , as shown in Fig. 11(b). The increase in the φ value reduces the adsorption strength of the intermediate because the metal atoms own more d orbital valence electrons due to the redistribution of the charge. With the downward movement of the energy level in the center of the d-band, the antibonding orbitals are occupied for the atomic orbitalhybridization between the metal atoms and the carbon atoms, resulting in a decrease in OH* adsorption. As such, selecting the correct metal ion based on what kind of localized electronic states it can introduce into the catalyst is very important because the electronic level of the transition metal dopants will directly control the catalytic performance. Zhang et al. [215] systematically studied the ORR/OER catalytic activity of four-coordinate nitrogen compounds (TMN4@G) system using DFT. The volcano plots constructed as a function of adsorption free energy and overpotential, as shown in Fig. 12 (a and b), show that Ir and Rh as metal centers have excellent OER and ORR catalytic activities. The metals on the right side of the volcano plot in Figure an exhibit weak O* bonding strength, while the metals on the left side show weak O–H bonds. The ORR/OER catalytic mechanism was deeply understood through charge density difference (CDD) calculations and Bader charge analysis. As shown in Fig. 12(c and d), charge transfer and redistribution occur between the adsorbed intermediate and the RhN4@G surface. O atoms in IrN4@G gain electrons from Ir or H atoms. Fig. 12(e and f) show the free energy distributions of the ORR/OER reaction pathways of IrN4@G and RhN4@G, respectively. From the analysis of the free energy barrier, O* to OOH* is the rate-determining step in the OER step for IrN4@G, while OOH* formed by O2 is the rate-determining step of ORR. The formation of O* from OH* in the OER of RhN4@G is the rate-determining step, while the conversion of OH* to H2O is the rate-determining step of ORR. The role of metals affects catalytic activity mainly through electron transfer and redistribution and by affecting the adsorption strength of intermediates. 3.1.2 Combination configuration of metal and N-doped carbon Transition metals are frequently used to modify N-doped carbon [216–218]. Studies have shown that carbon substrates help to expose many active centers, and Co-N ligands can serve as catalytic active centers [57,219]. The presence of N can trap more Co, and the coordination of N and Co can change the electron distribution [220]. Yu et al. [221] verified by DFT calculation that the Co-N interface in the Co-N-C hierarchical structure is the active center. Co-Co and Co-N ligands promote ORR, and the Co-O bond is beneficial to OER. Li et al. [184] used nitrogen-containing polymers (2,5-benzimidazole) as raw materials to synthesize two-dimensional-Fe, N-co-doped graphene (2D-Fe-NG) with excellent ORR/OER performance. Based on the poisoning experiments and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, Fe atoms exist in the form of Fe-N x coordination bonds and mainly affect the ORR performance, while graphitic nitrogen and pyridinic nitrogen are the main active components for catalyzing OER. The combined effect of carbon matrix and surface configuration can enhance the redox reaction kinetics and the intrinsic affinity of reaction intermediates [222,223]. The electrocatalytic ORR/OER processes are closely related to the redox processes of TM2+/TM3+. In general, transition metals have electronic d-orbitals and empty d-orbitals, which can provide empty orbitals to act as the electrophiles or lone pairs as nucleophiles. These two functions are beneficial to the breaking of the adsorption bond for forming intermediates and promoting product formation by reducing the activation energy. The empty d-orbitals of the active center can match the anti-bonding orbital of the reactive molecule, thereby effectively activating the bond that needs to be broken in the reactive molecule. The activated electron orbitals can make transition metals become potentially highly efficient catalysts [224]. 3.1.3 Synergistic effect of metal and N-doped carbon The complementary and synergistic effects between transition metals and N-doped carbon can optimize the charge transferability in the catalyst and increase the exposure of active centers [225]. This synergistic effect is likely induced by two aspects. On one hand, it is based on the chelation between the metal center and the N, O, S, P coordination sites in the carbon-based substrate. On the other hand, the covalent bond between the doped species and the carbon-based host material is beneficial to the π-π stacking or electrostatic interaction [226]. Although the underlying mechanism was not fully understood, the synergistic effect is widely utilized in preparing highly active catalyst materials. It is generally believed that the synergistic effect may be closely related to bridging between metal and active sites [185]. The bridging between metal ions and other elements such as N and C can modify oxygen-containing functional groups, enhance the coupling of heterogeneous species, and form related channels to accelerate electron transfer [227]. Han et al. [182] compared the oxygen reduction performance of Fe-N-C structure on carbon material and N-doped carbon material, from which they explained the principle of performance improvement based on the change in reaction free energies. As shown in Fig. 13 (a), N doping and Fe addition are the reasons for the change of free energy in different stages and dopants provide selectivity in favor of different reaction intermediates. As shown in Fig. 13(b), N doping also changes the electronic structure of the metal active center to a certain extent. After N doping, more charge is transferred from Fe-3d orbital to O-2p orbital. This charge transfer enhances the Fe-O bonding, which activates the O-containing species on the active center and enhances the catalytic activity. Ge et al. [183] studied the basic principle of performance improvement induced by the hybridization of metallic cobalt with N-doped carbon materials. Co atoms affect the optimization of catalytic performance. Compared with the presence of isolated Co, the coordination form of Co and N greatly changes the efficiency of electron transfer and intermediate adsorption. As shown in Fig. 13(c), the adsorption energy of OOH* formation reaction, as the limiting step of OER, is significantly strengthened after Co coordinating with N. This changes the OER reaction barrier and improvement in the catalytic reaction performance is correlated with the change in electronic structures. As shown in Fig. 13(d), the change in the density of states generates the high conductivity of Co4N. The center value of the d-band of Co4N is close to the Fermi level, giving rise to delocalized electrons which induce stronger catalytic activity. Ibraheem et al. [186] synthesized a coupled Fe2NiSe4@Fe-NC hybrid material, the Fe2NiSe4 nano-cube was formed by strong coupling of Fe-NC with a selenic-graphitic-nitrogen bond (Se-GNG). Different configurations of N such as quaternary-N, pyrrolic-N, Fe-N x , pyridinic-N, and oxidized-N were confirmed with XPS.
