The pyridinic-N is the dominant group in Fe2NiSe4@Fe-NC, but N 1s of the Fe/Ni control group does not change, indicating that the addition of Se can promote the formation of N species adsorption structure (Fig. 13e). The results show that the interaction between Se and N is strong, and the metal can be bonded to the C-N configuration to provide an energy-favorable TM-N configuration. SE-GNG bond helps electron transfer between metal and graphitic-N. Graphitic-N then receives electrons and converts them to pyridinic-N. The strong coupling interaction between Fe2NiSe4 and Fe-NC accelerates charge transfer, promotes the migration of electrolyte ions and stabilizes metal atoms. Compared with Pt/C and IrO2, the prepared Fe2NiSe4@Fe-NC catalyst showed higher ORR/OER activities and stability. As identified, the synergy between N-C and TM is that the combination of metal and N facilitates the adsorption of OOH* and the stretching of O-O bonds. But it influences the catalytic OER activity weakly. The identification of the specific location where the OER occurs is particularly important for studying high-efficiency catalysts. Qiu et al. [225] researched the synergistic effect of N and Ni in Ni, N co-doped three-dimensional porous graphene. The OER rate-limiting step is the formation of O* species in the Ni, N co-doped graphene, and N-doped graphene. The stability of O* intermediates also affects OER activity. The O* intermediate on the co-doped graphene forms a bond with C that can stabilize the O*, reducing O* and OH* intermediates. Tavakkoli et al. [187] verified that a catalyst composed of N, Co, and Mo co-doped graphene nanoflakes (GFs) and CNTs (N-Co-Mo-GF/CNT) on Ni substrate could form a new interfacial site as identified by scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), which induced a synergistic effect for enhancing the catalytic OER activity. As shown in Fig. 13(f), Oxygen generated during OER can be detected on the SECM probe near the surface of the substrate. Through the substrate generation-tip collection (SG-TC) SECM experiment on Ni substrate (Tip potential is 0.3 V, and the substrate potential was scanned in the OER region), it is found that oxygen takes longer to reach the tip, and the tip current gradually increases, as shown in Fig. 13(g). The experimental results indicated that OER occurred near the electrocatalyst/Ni interface rather than on the catalyst surface, and new active centers could be formed at the interface. The active center at the interface had a higher catalytic activity. Therefore, the further regulation mechanism of catalytic bifunctional ORR and OER activities should be explained by the effect of the interface effect. It is necessary to find the relationship between reaction energy and reactant/intermediate adsorption at the interface where the catalytic reaction occurs to optimize the activity. If the difference of electronegativities between metals and intermediate products is large, the shortening of the metal–oxygen bond and the lengthening of the O-O bond may be induced, meaning that there is a strong interaction between the adsorbate and the adsorption configuration, leading to higher ORR activity and lower OER activity. When the interaction between the catalyst and adsorbent is weak, the OER activity is higher when the electron transfer is less. By coordinating the bond environment of the active site at the reaction interface, the catalytic activities are expected to improve together significantly. 3.1.4 Optimization of catalyst structure and composition The combination of metal atoms and the N-C structure can become the new active centers for ORR and OER. However, the synthesis of most TM-N-C catalysts requires high-temperature pyrolysis, which leads to the coexistence of metal particles or carbides, resulting in the reduction of the activity of active species [228]. Through method optimization, the reduction of catalytic activity during the synthesis process of the metal carbon-based catalysts can be mitigated to a certain extent. Nandan et al. [188] synthesized a Fe-N x /C enriched carbon-based electrocatalyst by coating Fe-Fe3C in the wall of the hollow-structured NCNTs. The hollow structure inside the nanotube is similar to a bamboo chamber. They found that the activity of the catalytic active sites was produced by these doped atoms in the graphitized layers on the inner walls of carbon nanotubes and the active site content of the nanotubes was very low. Therefore, further opening of the nanotubes thus increasing the available activity sites is very important. In this regard, acid pickling to expose the closed nanotubes was proved to be a feasible method. Additionally, the hard template process commonly used in catalyst synthesis may have some limitations in preparing a favorable catalyst structure and shape. Removal of the template may also destroy the nanostructure, but a soft template can reduce this damage [229,230]. Li et al. [189] coupled the transition metal with porous hetero-doped carbon by the method of co-assembly of the soft template and carbon nitride polymer to prepare a FeNi alloy/N-doped carbon hybrid material (FeNi/NC) (Fig. 14 a). This FeNi/NC has an outstanding OER catalytic activity. The electrode potential is 1.58 V at 10 mA/cm2, which is lower than other samples such as FeNi alloy/N-doped carbon nanotubes (1.62 V), as well as carbon hybrid material and RuO2 (1.65 V), as shown in Fig. 14(b). This is mainly because the evenly distributed FeNi nano alloy particles could transform the outer carbon layer into OER active components through electron transfer. According to Tafel diagram in Fig. 14(c), FeNi/NC (95 mV/dec) has a lower OER Tafel slope. The LSV curve of the FeNi/NC catalyst demonstrates that the ORR half-wave potential is 0.81 V at 3 mA/cm2 and the ORR initial potential at 0.1 mA/cm2 is 0.98 V. The catalytic performance is similar to that of Pt/C (Fig. 14d). The ORR Tafel slope of FeNi/NC (77 mV/dec) is low, which is affected by the intermediate migration of the adsorbed oxygen (Fig. 14e). The three-dimensional porous structure and abundant defect sites of FeNi/NC bring high performance. The potential gap ΔE (0.77 V) is superior to the Pt/C + RuO2 catalyst. Some transition metal materials aggregate and oxidize due to the presence of unsaturated bonds, high diffusivity during high-temperature pyrolysis, and lack of fixed sites, which can also degrade their electrocatalytic properties by destroying and covering active sites [231]. Reducing the amount of peroxide in the catalytic reaction and adopting a hierarchical structure be beneficial in preventing the oxidation and self-aggregation of transition metals. For example, Sanetuntikul et al. [190] directly pyrolyzed cobalt amino acid chelate complex (COAAC) to produce Co, N co-doped porous carbon catalysts (CoNPCs). The CoNPC-71, CoNPC-81, and CoNPC-91 were products at different pyrolysis temperatures of 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C. From the half-wave potential and initial potential of the ORR polarization curves shown in Fig. 15 a, it can be found that the as-prepared Co, N co-doped catalysts, especially CoNPC-71, have lower overpotentials than Pt/C. The rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) experiment shows that ORR is a four-electron transfer process catalyzed by CoNPC-71, and the oxygen reduction process is promoted to make the peroxide content less (Fig. 15b). The K-L diagram further proves the four-electron transfer path of ORR (Fig. 15c). Similarly, compared to RuO2, the OER LSV curves of CoNPC-71 and CoNPC-91 catalysts have higher current density and lower overpotential (Fig. 15f). The excellent catalytic performance was mainly due to the appropriate mesoporous structure, a large amount of pyridine-N, and TM-N x structure synergy. Most importantly, the activity loss of the ORR and OER activities of CoNPCs after 10,000 and 2000 cycles respectively is negligible (Fig. 15d and e). Compared with Pt aggregation in Pt/C catalyst, the unique hierarchical microstructure of CoNPCs can function together with active centers to prevent the weakening of aggregation-induced activity and stability. The aggregation of a single type of metal can be inhibited by the formation of alloys with fixed sites. For example, Wang et al. [191] embedded bimetallic FeCu alloy into N-doped carbon nanotubes to inhibit the serious polymerization of copper. The lower ΔE value in the polarization curve shows that FeCu0.3-N/C is a bifunctional electrocatalyst with excellent performance. The ΔE values of this catalyst (0.777 V) are significantly lower than those of FeN/C, Pt/C, IrO2, and Cu–N/C. Furthermore, this catalyst can maintain nearly 90% of the initial current after running for 30000 s, showing outstanding stability. In this case, iron metal was anchored on the top and inner wall of the carbon nanotubes and used as a fixing site for copper. The presence of FeCu alloy formed a bimetallic active center and promoted a 4-electron transfer process of ORR without peroxide generation. The four-electron transfer process not only reduced the possibility of catalyst oxidation for improving chemical stability but also improved electrical conductivity and reduced the barrier for oxygen reaction. In addition, the carbon matrix with a closed structure and highly graphitized carbon contained few dangling bonds and defects, which could further prevent the attack of oxygen atoms and reduce oxidation corrosion [232]. 3.1.5 Catalytic mechanism summary In general, the bonding between the transition metal and carbon dominates the catalytic performance of bifunctional catalysts. The differences of electronegativities in the transition metal carbonitride polarize the adjacent carbon atoms and become active components. The combination of metal species and N-C can lead to a decrease in the charge of the central transition metal atom so that the electrons can be transferred to the adsorption intermediates by reducing the reaction energy barrier. The higher negative in the reaction intermediates leads to differences in bond lengths for the enhancement of activation properties. The short metal-O bonds and long O-O bonds generated by the addition of metals in N-doped carbon materials produce is an example for strengthening synergy [233]. Manipulating the electron transfer can control the formation of low-oxidizing intermediates in the catalytic reaction, reducing the oxidative corrosion of the carbon substrate and preventing activity degradation. In addition, the structure design of catalysts provides attachment sites for metal atoms to prevent self-aggregation of metal particles and form more active centers. This mechanism applies not only to pure metals and alloys, but also to metal compounds such as oxides. The energy level changes between metal ions and between metal and carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, and other atoms affect the change of catalytic activity. The macroscopic optimization of the catalyst reflects the energy level change in principle. Through the introduction of heteroatoms and defects, and the hybridization between different materials, the Fermi level of the active site is changed, and the electron transfer and intermediate adsorption energy are optimized. The selection criteria of transition metals in N-doped carbon materials should take into account the changes in energy levels of metals and carbon. With the addition of transition metals, the electron transfer rate should be greatly increased and the adsorption strength of intermediates should be enhanced. The adsorption strength of the catalytic intermediate needs to reach the appropriate level for optimal catalytic performance. The d-band of metal is lowered in energy in the hybrid system of metal/carbon hybrid material because of the electron-withdrawing properties of carbon materials, thereby reducing the binding energy of the intermediate [234]. The adsorption strength of ORR intermediates is strong for Fe-N-C. The addition of Fe can effectively optimize the adsorption strength of ORR intermediates. The weak adsorption strength of ORR intermediates in Co-N-C makes it difficult to achieve efficient and fast adsorption and catalytic reactions. The combination of carbon material and Co-N has little effect on the optimization of adsorption strength. The ORR catalysis of the Fe-N-C system has obvious advantages. The transition metal can also reduce the Fermi level of the carbon material, thereby reducing the electron transfer barrier and the free energy for the adsorption of reaction intermediates [235]. For OER, the energy difference between the Fermi level of carbon and C-O determines the reaction kinetics [236]. The transition metals with high work function can be used as effective electron acceptors to absorb electrons in carbon materials, reducing Fermi energy levels of carbon materials and generating a rapid transfer of intermediate electrons to the active site. Transition metals can be used as active centers and can also be used to activate carbon active centers. The function of adding multivalence metals atoms or multiple metals atoms into the N-doped carbon material is to simultaneously modify the electron density or valence electrons of the metal atoms and the carbon atoms to control the Fermi energy level and accelerate the electron transfer. Transition metals and N-doped carbon materials interact and coordinate with each other at the energy level. The matching effect was used to control the Fermi level of the active site to a suitable energy band to optimize the adsorption of ORR and OER intermediates. 3.2 Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) derived catalysts The MOFs formed by metals and organic ligands have high specific surface areas and controllable structures [237,238]. After high-temperature calcination and pyrolysis of MOFs frame, the heteroatom doped carbon materials with different structures can be obtained, which have shown catalytic ORR/OER activities [239,240]. In recent years, the introduction of MOFs-based materials as carriers or precursors is a common approach for catalyst optimization [241–243]. MOFs have great potential for component and structure design because the infinite nature of reticular chemistry can be delicately controlled. Through the addressability of network chemistry, the control of molecular building units such as MOFs can be achieved to influence the control of structure and active sites [244]. Therefore, a variety of microstructures can be prepared using different components and methods [245]. Carbon framework and metal coordination sites bring stable organic–inorganic internal hybridization. Inherent non-coordination metal sites can also act as activity sites by controlling the coordination environment [246]. The pores in the MOFs structure can be changed to optimize the mass transfer efficiency [247]. In addition, MOFs also contain more coordination bonds, defects, and metal atom coordination sites, which are used to stabilize the active center and connect reaction intermediates [248]. The current problems faced by MOFs electrocatalysts are mainly focused on conductivity, catalytic activity, and stability. The inherent conductivity of organic and inorganic coordination structures in MOFs is too low to maintain effective electron transfer [249]. Due to the saturation of metal sites and the limitation of the framework, there are few effective active sites in MOFs, which further limits their catalytic performance [250]. The stability of MOFs in neutral electrolytes is limited because the coordination bond is weak and the framework structure is prone to hydrolysis and collapse, and it is more difficult to maintain activity under extreme acid-base conditions [251]. These problems can be improved by surface regulation, such as the formation of composite interfaces [252], and doping optimization of atoms and structural optimization, such as the formation of structures that expose more active sites [253]. The combination of MOFs and carbon substrates allows the catalyst to harness the advantages from both components as shown in Fig. 16 . MOFs have many catalytic advantages, such as heteroatom doping, and active substance encapsulations, more exposed active sites. The transport channels and hierarchical microstructure of carbon materials further provide sites and protect active species. 3.2.1 Optimization of MOFs conductivity MOFs are rarely used directly as electrocatalysts because of their poor mass transfer rate and electrical conductivity [254]. However, MOFs can be pyrolyzed to form metal-doped or non-metal conductive carbon materials, which have excellent catalytic activity and oxidation–reduction resistance [255]. For example, Qian et al. [133] synthesized B, N co-doped porous carbon material by pyrolyzing a Zn-MOF under the atmosphere of the H2-Ar mixture. It was found that the design of catalyst with fine microstructure using MOFs could mitigate the problem of uneven dispersion of the second carbon phase in the traditional carbon structure. The positively charged C atoms near the doped atoms provided channels for electron and reactant transfer. The combination of MOFs and various conductive carbon materials can construct mass and electron transfer channels to improve catalytic performance. Xiong et al. [200] prepared a ZIF-67@HMCS hybrid material with a yolk-shell structure by combining a mesoporous carbon sphere (HMCS) and ZIF-67, as shown in Fig. 17 (a). The catalytic activity of the ZIF-67@HMCS hybrid material was significantly increased due to the synergistic effect. ZIF-67 might be transformed into amorphous Co(OH)2 as the OER active center. As shown in Fig. 17(b), the synergy of ZIF-67 and HMCS can also increase the Co-N x active site of ORR. The ORR half-wave potential of ZIF@HMCS-25% (with HMCS content of 25%) is 0.823 V. The Tafel slope (41.9 mV/dec) of this catalyst is lower than that of Pt/C. This low Tafel slope may be derived from the layered pore structure of HMCS, which can promote the transfers of both electrolytes and electrons thus improving the reaction kinetics (Fig. 17c). The results of the accelerated durability test of ZIF@HMCS-25% show that the current density decrease only slightly after 2000 CV cycles. The chronoamperometric result shows that the current density of 84.5% is maintained after 28,000 seconds of cycling, indicating its high stability in an alkaline medium (Fig. 17d). This high stability should originate from the shell which can protect from alkaline corrosion. As shown in Fig. 17(e and f) for OER activity, the overpotential of ZIF@HMCS-25% is lower than that of IrO2 catalyst, and the Tafel slope (99.3 mV/dec) is also close to that of IrO2. When this ZIF@HMCS-25% was used in a battery, the charge and discharge processes were improved, as shown in Fig. 17(g). Therefore, the hierarchical porous structure induced by the HMCS content is an important factor affecting catalytic performance through controlling the particle size of ZIF-67, shortening the diffusion path, and enhancing the ion transport. The packaging structure not only improves the conductivity but also accelerates mass transfer and protects active centers. 3.2.2 Metal active centers of MOFs The metal center in MOFs-derived materials plays a key role in promoting adsorption [256–259]. Yan et al. [201] used Ni-MOF and graphene oxide as raw materials to form a 3D carbon nanotube (CNT)/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) heterostructure film (CGHF) (called Ni@N-HCGHF) (Fig. 18 a). The study found that Ni interacted with N-doped carbon after MOF pyrolysis. Electron transfer from a nickel to carbon shell layer optimizes the adsorption reaction and reduces the reaction overpotential. As shown in Fig. 18(b), CNTs and rGO formed an interconnected heterostructure, and Ni was encapsulated in the multilayer carbon to prevent oxidation and aggregation. The roles and advantages of metal sites in OER (Fig. 18c) and ORR (Fig. 18d) were further analyzed from the free energy diagrams. In OER and ORR, Ni@NC has a lower reaction energy barrier than N-C with favorable kinetics. The transition between OOH* and O* is the rate determining step. This excellent catalytic kinetics is due to the electron transfer from the metal to the C atom, which strengthens the C–H bond and reduces the free energy of the intermediate, accelerating the formation of OOH*. Li et al. [260] prepared catalysts of CoN x C on N-doped porous carbon nanofibers (CoNC@N-CNF) using bimetal-ZIFs, and investigated the chemical state, surface composition, doping and elemental bonding of CoNC@N-CNF by XPS. As shown in Fig. 18(e), there are peaks of C-N, C=N, C=C, indicating a higher degree of graphitization. The peaks of metallic Co, Co-N x and Co oxide are shown in the XPS spectrum of Co 2p (Fig. 18f). The numerous Co-N x configurations shown in the XPS map of N 1s act as ORR active sites (Fig. 18g). This further illustrates that the bonding and electron transfer between metal and N-C are important reasons for the efficient catalytic activity. MOFs can also be used as doping sources for further surface doping and hybrid modification of the original carbon substrate [261]. For example, Wei et al. [202] prepared Mn-doped ZIF-67 as a pyrolysis precursor by a solution impregnation method to obtain an Mn, Co, and N co-doped carbon catalyst (Mn/Co-N-C). The dodecahedral microstructure of this Mn/Co-N-C catalyst was stable in morphology, and the electronic structure of Co and electrocatalytic ORR/OER activities were improved after Mn doping. This Mn/Co-N-C catalyst could have higher active centers because of the synergistic effect between Mn and Co. This synergistic effect might be induced by the coupling between tetravalent Mn center and trivalent Co nucleus after Mn doping in Co-N-C. The Mn site provided terminal oxygen groups to promote the O-O bond formation, while the Co site helped excite electron-hole pairs for promoting OER activity. A proper amount of doped Mn not only improves the conductivity of the catalyst but also affects the C structure of the electronic cobalt center and enhances its activity. Therefore, transition metal ions with mixed-valence states can provide donor–acceptor centers for oxygen adsorption and facilitate the electronic transfer, leading to the enhancement of the catalytic performance [243]. Importantly, the synergy between the individual active components also helps to optimize the bonding strength of the intermediate and the mass of reactants/electron transfer, to generate excellent catalytic activity. 3.2.3 Special structure regulation of MOFs As the precursors of bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts, MOFs are prone to carbonization at high temperatures, resulting in structural damage of the MOFs [262]. The destruction of MOFs structure can lead to decreases in nitrogen content, pore diameter, and specific surface area. Non-noble metal carbon-based catalysts can improve uneven dispersion of the second carbon phase and reduction of the active center of MOFs caused by carbon coating through designing encapsulation and yolk-shell structure of hollow mesoporous carbon spheres (HMCS) [263]. In this regard, the innovative arrangement of reducing or oxidizing atmosphere in preparing catalysts should be able to avoid the destruction of MOFs structure during pyrolysis of carbon materials. Aijaz et al. [203] synthesized core–shell Co@Co3O4 nanoparticles embedded in CNT grafted N-doped carbon polyhedron and used as bifunctional ORR/OER catalyst. In the H2 atmosphere, the MOFs phase was reduced and carbonized to maintain high graphitized carbon. In the O2 atmosphere, the carbonized products were oxidized and calcined into amorphous carbon. These two steps could optimize the structure and maintain the carbon skeleton. This core–shell structured catalyst derived from MOFs could avoid metal accumulation, low graphitization degree, and poor carbon/metal contact in the synthesis process [264]. Feng et al. [265] prepared bamboo-shaped N-doped carbon nanofibers coated NiCo nanoparticle (NiCo-X@N-CNFs-T) (X = Ni/Co ratios, T = Carbonization temperature) using an electrostatic spinning technique (Fig. 19 a). The potential difference ΔE (ΔE = E j=10 - E 1/2) of NiCo-0.8@N-CNFs-800 catalyst is 0.79 V. Compared with Pt/C and RuO2, this catalyst showed higher stability, durability, and methanol resistance. As shown in Fig. 19(b-d), metal nanoparticles are coated with a stable bamboo shell to prevent oxidation and corrosion of highly active nanoparticles in the electrolyte environment. The ordered arrangement of carbon nanofibers can provide a favorable oxygen reaction interface, and the pore structure can provide oxygen capture sites and electron transport channels. Furthermore, the bamboo structure obtained by carbonization can increase the reaction interface and expose active centers for facilitating the efficiency of electron transport. Qi et al. [266] coated Co/Co4N nanoparticles and N-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs) on rGO to form a catalyst of Co/Co4N@N-CNTs/rGO. As shown in Fig. 19(e-g), N-CNTs are evenly distributed on the surface of rGO. Metal nanoparticles are coated on the top of the nanotubes, which can prevent the aggregation and spalling of the catalytic active center during cycling. The core–shell structure makes the Co/Co4N particles more closely in contact with the outer layer carbon, improving the electron exchange rate. This structure is also the key in inhibiting aggregation of Co/Co4N particles for improving the contact between N-CNTs and Co-based species, and to some extent making up for the defects of typical MOFs materials. The optimization of MOFs for catalytic performance focuses on the structure and active sites. The conductivity can be optimized by combining MOFs materials with conductive substrates, such as graphitic carbon materials, and changing microstructures, such as two-dimensional nanosheets through novel preparation methods. Using MOFs as a template can first dope more metal active centers, and then expose effective active sites through pyrolysis or in-situ decomposition, which can increase effective the active sites, enhance the catalytic activity, and promote stability. MOFs can be employed as precursors to form specifically structured catalysts such as bamboo-shaped nanotubes to protect active sites, prevent corrosion of acid-base electrolytes, and further enhance catalytic stability. The method of using MOFs as precursors or templates to optimize catalysts can be widely adopted to fabricate more types of catalysts because of the rich structural types and chemistries in MOFs. 4 Application of carbon-based electrocatalysts in metal-air battery Being green, safe, and highly efficient, metal-air batteries possess a tremendous potential to develop advanced energy harvesting and conversion devices (Fig. 20 ). At the present, metal-air batteries have been dominated by zinc(lithium)-air batteries, which are primarily focusing on the preparation of advanced ORR/OER dual-functional catalysts to be used for the electrodes in the metal-air barriers. In particular, transition metal carbon-based catalysts hold the potential for this purpose [267]. Typically, the ORR/OER in cathodes suffers from slow reaction kinetics, which greatly limits the charge–discharge efficiency, energy efficiency, and cycle stability of metal-air batteries [268]. Fabrication of efficient and stable ORR/OER catalysts to improve the efficiency of cathode reactions in metal-air batteries is a research focus in this field. With better ORR/OER catalysts, the improvements in the efficiencies of the metal-air battery come in two-fold: the excellent OER activity lowers the charging voltage of the battery, which prevents the ORR activity to be weakened under a positive voltage [223], the latter is the chemical reaction that determines the discharge ability at the negative electrode [269]. The carbon-based bifunctional catalyst can improve battery performance for the presence of abundant active sites and rich microstructures in the catalyst [277]. The performance of some representative carbon-based catalysts and the metal-air batteries constructed with these catalysts are listed [270–274], as shown in Fig. 21 . It can be seen from Fig. 21, that the ΔE of the catalysts, the specific capacity, and the open-circuit voltage show some degree of correlation. This shows that, to a certain extent, by optimizing the catalytic performance of the ORR/OER dual-function catalyst, the metal-air battery fabricated with the optimized catalyst can deliver high power density and specific capacity, long-term cycle stability, and low charge–discharge voltage gap. Zhang et al. [155] prepared an ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst of ultrafine NiFe2O4 nano-quantum dots uniformly dispersed on carbon nanotubes (NiFe2O4(QDs)/CNTs) and used the catalyst to construct a zinc-air battery to illustrate the key parameters. The NiFe2O4(QDs)/CNTs dual-function catalyst showed outstanding ORR and OER catalytic performance. The low overpotentials of only 0.33 and 0.52 eV, respectively. The activity of the catalyst regulates the charge–discharge efficiency and the voltage difference by affecting the adsorption of reactants and the transfer of electrons. Both zinc/magnesium-air batteries constructed by NiFe2O4(QDs)/CNTs exhibit excellent performance, such as high energy density (275 mW/cm2 and 685 mW/cm2), specific capacity (801 mAh/g and 1652 mAh/g), and low charge–discharge voltage gap (0.62 V). The stability of the metal-air charge–discharge cycle is an extremely important performance parameter of the battery. It directly determines whether the battery is practically useful under real application scenarios. The zinc-air battery constructed with NiFe2O4(QDs)/CNTs has long-term charge–discharge cycle stability of more than 800 hours under conditions of 10 mA/cm2 and 20 min/cycle. This is due to the better cycle stability of NiFe2O4(QDs)/CNTs than Pt/C + IrO2. Uniformly dispersed small-size quantum dots acting as the active sites on the three-dimensional structural support optimize the catalytic performance, which further improves the cathode reaction rate in the metal-air battery. Improving the efficiency of the electrochemical reaction system of the battery and reducing the polarization of the battery are the keys to the study of small, high-power, and safe batteries. Both of these can be achieved with the application of highly active catalysts. The structure and components adjustment of the catalyst can also bring about effective battery performance optimization for metal-air batteries. Liu et al. [275] prepared a catalyst with ultrafine CoFe nanoalloys supported on N-doped hollow carbon microspheres (N-HCSs) for ORR/OER. Here the sizes of the CoFe alloy are becoming limited by the pore sizes of the hollow carbon, which promotes the CoFe active sites to be uniformly dispersed within the catalyst. The discharge current (147.2 mA/cm2) and power density (96.5 mW/cm2) of the zinc-air battery based on CoFe/N-HCSs are lower than the corresponding performances based on Pt/C (189.6 mA/cm2 and 117.9 mW/cm2) due to relatively low ORR activity, as shown in Fig. 22 (a). The voltage gaps of the corresponding batteries of CoFe/N-HCSs and Pt/C are very close (Fig. 22b), indicating that the battery has excellent charge and discharge reversibility. The light-emitting diode (LED) is connected and triggered at 1.387 V to verify the feasibility of actual battery operation, as shown in Fig. 22(c). The comparison of the voltage gap and cycling stability of different electrode catalysts is shown in Fig. 22(d). The zinc-air battery of CoFe/N-HCSs has a smaller voltage gap and higher energy efficiency than the battery of Pt/C, both before and after multiple charges and discharge cycles, which further illustrates that the catalyst has a significant impact on the battery's charge and discharge performance and stability. The unique structure of the carbon-based catalysts accelerates the transfer of intermediate products and electrons in the reaction process, thereby optimizing the battery performance. The advantage brought by the unique structures of carbon catalyst is also reflected in the protection of carbon-coated metal nanoparticles, such as preventing recrystallization and decomposition of the metal particles, to sustain the long-term performance of metal-air batteries. Zhang et al. [276] prepared a FeCo nanocrystal encapsulated in porous carbon support with a well graphitic-N-doped carbon shell (FeCo@NC-g) and a defect-rich carbon shell (FeCo@NC-d) for performance comparison. The polarization curves of the battery composed of the two catalysts are shown in Fig. 22(e). The battery composed of FeCo@NC-g has a low charge voltage and a high discharge voltage, which proves that the battery has better charge ability and energy efficiency. Fig. 22(f) shows that the FeCo@NC-g battery has a higher power density (190.2 mW/cm2), compared to Pt/C-IrO2 (139.1 mW/cm2) and FeCo@NC-d (118.5 mW/cm2). As shown in Fig. 22(g), the voltage gap (ΔE) of the FeCo@NC-g-based battery only increased from 0.65 V to 0.79 V after 120 cycles. This extremely small loss of voltage efficiency shows that the FeCo@NC-g battery has excellent charge–discharge cycle stability. As a carbon substrate, ordered graphitized carbon can ensure that the coated active center is not destroyed during the reaction, while the defective carbon shell cannot be protected. The unprotected metal particles will be converted into hydroxides or oxyhydroxides in the alkaline environment with the application of voltage. The process is irreversible and the formation of hydroxides or oxyhydroxides will greatly reduce ORR activity and battery performance. 5 Summary and perspectives 5.1 Summary The research progress in bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts is reviewed in terms of their catalytic performance. To achieve excellent catalytic performance, the structural control and surface engineering of the bifunctional catalysts are considered the most promising strategies. During the catalytic processes, the mass transport of reaction intermediates/products and electron transfer on the catalyst surface are the critical steps determining the overall reaction rates. In this regard, different carbon structures such as nanotubes, nanosheets, and hollow nanospheres can provide large specific surface areas to expose more effective catalytic reaction active centers for corresponding catalytic reactions. The mesoporous structure and the layered structure can provide the transport channels for reactants/intermediates, favoriting the catalytic reactions. Regarding transition metals-composited heteroatoms-doped carbon catalysts, core–shell structured ones can protect the metal from aggregation and heterogeneous contact, thereby improving the stability of the catalyst. Surface engineering of bifunctional catalysts can create suitable surface structures with highly active sites for promoting electron transfer, improve hydrophilicity and oxygen adsorption efficiency, reduce the catalytic reaction barriers, and facilitate the diffusion of reactants/intermediates. Due to the difference in electron energy levels, different valences or different types of surface dopants can change the electronegativity and energy barrier of surrounding atoms for achieving the purpose of optimized species adsorption and electron transfer. Through employing effective surface engineering, the electronic structures of the catalysts can be modified. This is achieved by changing the bonding structures of the stable active centers via strategies such as heteroatom doping as well as the introduction of defects. The addition of metals and their oxides can further regulate the interface bond patterns, thus further enhancing the synergistic effects in the electrocatalytic process. 5.2 Emphasis on catalytic parameters As discussed, the presence of diffusion resistance during mass transport can have a significant impact on the kinetics of the chemical reaction. The microstructure should be regulated by constructing a reasonable hierarchical microstructure, reducing the size of the catalyst, and increasing the inner diameter of pores. These strategies can reduce the transport time of reactants/products in the channels, increase the selectivity of the catalytic reaction and reduce the diffusion barriers. For example, a core–shell structured catalyst can prevent active centers from being destroyed by environmental corrosion and inhibit the aggregation of metal active centers. Electrocatalytic processes usually involve the formation and breaking of adsorptive bonds on the catalytic reaction interface. The adsorption energy represents the electrochemical coupling which can define the catalytic activity of the surface reactants to some extent because the interfacial electron coupling of the catalytic reaction characterizes the catalytic activity. It is difficult to form a suitable adsorption state due to the weak adsorption, while the catalyst with strong adsorption is easy to result in deactivation. Based on this knowledge, finding an appropriate adsorptive state is crucial in understanding reaction mechanisms for ORR/OER dual catalytic reaction. The bidentate adsorption of oxygen can promote the four-electron transfer and realize efficient ORR. Regarding the OER reaction, the possible processes of oxygen formation in the adsorbed state are as follows: coupling of O atoms at the top; breaking of O-O bond after two hydrolyses of –OH; and the loss of protons in –OOH species. All these processes involve four proton-electron coordination transfers, therefore, high OER activity can be obtained through the favorable adsorption state of oxygen. The optimal oxygen adsorption state can promote the four-electron transfer process of ORR and OER because the reaction mechanisms are all determined by the adsorption configurations. Active sites with selective adsorption for various intermediates can be constructed to further explore the dual catalytic mechanism [278]. The best adsorption state can be obtained by optimizing the structure and surface electronic state of the catalyst. In addition, the superhydrophobic surface produced by surface engineering can also regulate the adsorption and desorption states of the products. There are differences in energy level and charge density between the active groups and the unmodified substrate. These differences can promote electron transfer and activate the reaction, which then further enhances the catalytic activity. In addition, combining active material with a conductive matrix can also enhance the conductivity of the catalytic interface for improving electron transferability. Mass diffusion, reactant adsorption, and electron transfer are the prerequisites for the occurrence of catalytic reactions. The level of reaction barrier is the decisive factor limiting catalytic performance. Formation and exposure of more active sites can lower the reaction barrier. The large surface area can provide enough adsorption centers and active sites to ensure the formation of optimal adsorption states, and the active groups formed by doping and defects can provide proper surface charge to control the bond length of the adsorbed state and obtain lower overpotential. Moreover, the surface adsorption bond can be used as an electron channel to promote the electron transfer thus further reducing the reaction barrier. Therefore, structure control and surface optimization can influence the reaction pathways, thus promoting the efficient, rapid, and stable occurrence of catalytic reactions. 5.3 Challenges and possible further approaches Although the research and development of bifunctional ORR/OER carbon-based catalysts have gained progress, the following challenges still need to be overcome in terms of practical applications in electrochemical energy conversion devices: (1) The current ORR/OER carbon-based catalysts fabrication methods usually include multi-steps, which are cumbersome and costly with serious loss of raw materials and poor controllability of products. These methods are unable to fully achieve the desired catalyst morphologies and catalytic performances. Therefore, the development of simple, effective, and controllable synthetic methods is particularly critical. (2) There are difficulties in achieving optimized surface structures of the catalyst although the mesoporous structure and core–shell structure can provide sufficient active sites. For example, too high pore density of porous graphene can compromise the electron transfer to active sites, and carbonization of MOFs template may destroy the original microstructure of MOFs during the pyrolysis process. For favorable microstructure design, not only sufficient specific surface area and large pores for the catalytic activity should be considered, but the stability of catalysts is particularly important. (3) Although both heteroatoms doping and defect creation are employed in surface engineering, they can bring about problems such as dopant agglomeration and corrosion. In general, the content and distribution of active centers still cannot be precisely regulated in the process of surface engineering. It is recommended to try different contents and types of elements doping to obtain more stable functional groups as the catalytic active centers. The co-doping of metal with N, P, and other elements can be used to further control the charge around the metal center to further improve the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates [279]. It is feasible to control the type and number of defects through surface engineering to obtain the best performance of the defective rich catalysts. Furthermore, controlling defects and phase distributions through lattice strain and phase transition can indirectly optimize the activity and stability of catalysts [280]. (4) There is insufficient control of crystal surfaces for obtaining low-loading catalysts with high catalytic performance. The different atomic arrangements on various crystal surfaces can result in a variety of electronic structures. Hence, different surfaces possess various adsorption energies on the active centers. It is very important to find the crystal facets with the best adsorption sites to further enhance the catalytic activity. For nanoparticle catalysts, detailed studies on the particle morphologies on the atomistic level are critical for providing evidence on the location of active centers. (5) There is an insufficient exploration of the synergetic effects for enhancing catalyst performance. As recognized, the synergistic effect is one of the most desired effects in catalyst preparation and catalytic performance. Through the combination of different modification strategies, a great enhancement effect can be achieved. However, the random combination of different modification methods may not lead to synergistic enhancement, even deterioration in the catalytic performances. The synergistic effect is not only explained by ion bridging but analyzed by different microstructures and sizes, compositions, and even environments. Exploring corporative electronic effects and optimizing electrochemical reaction conditions is a new design idea [281–285]. We believe that the key challenge is to have a deeper understanding and effective application of synergy with the aids of theoretical calculation and machine learning based on the published results. Therefore, to obtain the best strategy of modification technology, it is of great significance to further undertake comprehensive theoretical studies of the synergistic effect through emerging computing methods such as simulation computing and machine learning. (6) It is still insufficient in the fundamental understanding of the enhancement mechanisms of some structural design and surface engineering in terms of the catalyzed ORR/OER processes. The combination of electrochemical measurements and reaction process characterization using in-situ characterization techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD) technology, synchrotron radiation, Raman, etc. and theoretical calculations such as DFT to analyze active components and reaction intermediates to enrich our fundamental understanding of the reaction mechanisms of catalysts [286]. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysts are one of the essential components for the devices of high-efficiency green energy storage and conversion, such as metal-air cells, fuel cells, and water electrolysis systems. While catalysts made from noble metals possess high catalytic performance in both oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), their scarcity and expensiveness significantly limit large-scale applications. In this regard, metal-free/non-noble metal carbon-based catalysts have become competitive alternatives to replace catalysts made of noble metals. Nevertheless, low catalytic ORR/OER performance is the challenge of carbon-based catalysts for the commercial applications of metal-air batteries. To solve the problem of poor catalytic performance, two strategies have been proposed: (1) controlling the microstructure of the catalysts to expose more active sites as the channels of rapid mass and electron transfer; and (2) reducing the reaction energy barrier by optimizing the electronic structures of the catalysts via surface engineering. Here, we review different types of bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts with the activated surface sites. We focus on how the challenge can be overcome with different methods of material synthesis, structural and surface characterization, performance validation/optimization, to outline the principles of surface modifications behind catalyst designs. In particular, we provide critical analysis in the challenges that we are facing in structural design and surface engineering of bifunctional ORR/OER catalysts and indicate the possible solution for these problems, providing the society with clearer ideas on the practical prospects of noble-metal-free electrocatalysts for their future applications.

coredata.dc:title: Carbon-based bifunctional electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions: Optimization strategies and mechanistic analysis
